input_context.project: Responsible AI Skills for Civil Service Modernization
input_context.region: National with pilot cohorts in Astana and Almaty
input_context.problem: Civil servants across central and selected regional government bodies have uneven practical skills in safe, ethical, and effective AI use for public administration, limiting service delivery modernization and workflow efficiency.
input_context.target_population: Mid-level and senior civil servants in policy, service delivery, digital transformation, and administrative units across participating government agencies.
input_context.goal: Improve public sector efficiency and service quality through responsible, institutionalized AI use in government workflows.
input_context.development_objective: Strengthen the institutional capacity of participating government agencies in Kazakhstan to safely and effectively apply AI in priority administrative and service delivery functions.
intermediate_results: Civil servants improve practical competencies in responsible AI use for public administration tasks.
Participating agencies adopt foundational AI governance guidance, SOPs, and oversight practices.
Pilot units demonstrate measurable improvements in selected workflow efficiency and service delivery processes.
key_activities: Conduct agency needs assessment and baseline competency mapping
Develop curriculum on AI literacy, responsible use, ethics, and governance
Deliver training-of-trainers and cohort-based training programs
Run applied labs for policy analysis, document workflows, and citizen service use cases
Support drafting and adoption of AI SOPs and implementation guidance
Implement MEL framework, adoption tracking, and learning reviews
input_context.expected_change: By the end of 2027, participating agencies have trained staff, basic governance mechanisms, and piloted AI-enabled workflows that improve speed, consistency, and quality of selected public administration functions while maintaining human oversight.
cross_cutting_considerations: Data protection and information security compliance
Equitable access across agencies and regions
assumptions: Participating agencies authorize training delivery and supervised use of approved AI tools in training and pilot environments.
Leadership sponsors designate focal points and allocate staff time.
Access to relevant administrative workflow data and process maps is available for pilot design.
risks: Restrictions on AI tool access in government IT environments
Low institutional adoption after training without leadership follow-through
Staff turnover reduces retention of trained capacity
Data governance constraints delay pilot implementation
input_context.sustainability: Institutionalize capacity through training-of-trainers, agency focal points, SOPs and guidance, and refresher training embedded in civil service professional development structures.
mel_priorities: Adoption of AI governance and SOP practices
Quality and compliance of AI-assisted outputs

input_context.project: Responsible AI Governance and Civil Service Readiness
input_context.problem: Government institutions are under pressure to modernize administrative processes but lack practical skills, governance guidance, and safe-use standards for responsible AI adoption.
input_context.target_population: Civil servants and reform units in ministries and public service agencies.
input_context.expected_change: Public institutions improve readiness for responsible AI adoption through staff training, governance guidance, and pilot use cases.
key_activities: Rapid institutional readiness assessment
Short-cycle training on responsible AI use for public administration
Drafting of basic AI governance guidance and SOP templates
Pilot support for selected administrative workflows

input_context.project: Digital Governance Service Quality and Administrative Capacity
input_context.problem: Public institutions face uneven digital service management capacity, resulting in inconsistent service quality, long processing times, and weak citizen feedback integration.
input_context.target_population: Civil servants and municipal service managers in digital transformation, administrative services, and public service delivery units.
input_context.expected_change: Participating institutions improve digital service management practices, adopt standardized service quality procedures, and demonstrate measurable gains in processing efficiency and citizen responsiveness.
key_activities: Institutional capacity and service workflow assessments
Training on service design, digital process improvement, and data-informed management
Coaching for municipal and agency service teams
Support for standard operating procedures and service quality dashboards
Peer learning and performance review workshops

input_context.project: Public Sector Performance and Service Delivery Capacity Strengthening
input_context.region: National ministries and selected subnational administrations
input_context.problem: Public sector agencies have uneven capabilities in performance management, process optimization, and evidence-based decision-making, limiting consistent service delivery improvements.
input_context.target_population: Government managers, reform units, and civil servants in performance management and service delivery functions.
input_context.expected_change: Participating institutions adopt stronger performance management and service improvement practices, improve coordination across units, and achieve measurable gains in selected service delivery indicators.
key_activities: Institutional diagnostics and process mapping
Capacity development for performance management and data use
Technical assistance to design service improvement plans
Pilots for process optimization in selected agencies
Monitoring, learning, and adaptive management reviews
